oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Correspondence from Robert Rutledge to G. R. Rutledge, April 8, 1864
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation:
[Page 1]
“Uncle Sams. Apr 8th 1864 Dear Father I redc a letter from Minerva yesterday telling me that all the family were well with the exception of yourself. And as my letters will be of more interest to you than any one else upon account of locality I have concluded to answer Minervas letter by writing to you I wrote to Minerva a few days ago from Aunt Elziras. in that for you I gave the encampment of the different Brigades. for fear that the letter may not reach you I will tell you in this how we are encamped. Gen Buckner has resumed Command of his Division and has his Hed Quarters upon the hill we used to call the old Orchard. it is on the hill that is directly opposite the front end of Aunt Elziras house All around him are scattered Provost Guards and waggon trains &c. Johnsons Brigade is encamped in the woods between the Old Buher field and the road. You remember that square of eight or ten acres it is now pretty much cut down. Graceys Brigade is encamped back of the plantation next to where Sam Millard and Aunt Elziras mother used to live. Laws Brigade is encamped about opposite the old clover field on Uncle Sams and the Old Edwards farm A Battallion of Artiliry is encamped in the woods directly back of the old White top place. Waggon Trains and Quarter Master and Company quarters are scattered all about on Uncle Sams and Aunt Elziras, and the Buher farm. The fences are all torn down in every direction, and Aunt Elzira and Uncle Sam I fear will be prevented from making any crop this year. Aunt Elziras Negroes are doing no good. They steal from her about as fast as they make. They have even been stealing and selling hay I do not know what the Citizens here are to do if we remain much longer where we are. Aunt Elzira sold her best horse to a gap soldier for $800.00 on a short credit and has never herd anything from the man since. I consider his note as worth nothing Felix Earnist is going to Richmond on some business and I gave him the note to try the young mans”
[Page 2]
“Father and see if he will pay the det, but I understand that he has been disenhereted by his Father for bad conduct and I fear Mr Earnest will not get the money for Aunt Elzira Aunt Elzira is in a great deal of trouble and I do not know how she will make out for the next year. Went down and saw Uncle George Anderson and Aunt Elza a few days ago. They are all well, and are still living with John Anderson. The Country that we have evacuated is swept of every thing families almost everywhere have been robbed by the soldiers. They are robbing the Citizens around here of every thing they have to eat. The Country we have passed over is said not to have a Hog goose duck turkey or chicken or sheep left. Starvation is now staring many a poor defenseless Southern woman and many many poor helpless little children in the face Our Army is getting to be as much dreaded as the low down thieving Yankees. Some of the Alabamiens went a few days ago to a mill near here and found some ground Plaster in an old bolting chist and thinking it was Shirts they stold several Haversacks full of it, and after they had got it baked they said they had never seen such bread as that before. (this is a matter of fact) Tim Millers Brother of Capt Sam is dead. The funeral procession has just passed here a few minutes ago. Said to have died from excitement and trouble. I went up to Bristol a few days ago and got the promise of a shoe pattern. From Alf Carmack. For $16.00, his common price is $24.00. I staid all night with him They send their respects to the family Uncle George Andersons Aunt Elziras and Uncle Sams families, are all well with the exception of Catherine who is only slightly sick. They all send respects to the family. Hope Gamble will soon be exchanged and get a furlough to come home and stay with you for a while. I have not felt right well for several days but am knocking about, and drilling. Think we will leave here before long. Think at best the principal portion of the Army will shortly go to Va probably all but Buckners Division. Lt Brittian has returned. You and Minerva must write soon As ever your Son RARutledge”
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Letter from Robert Rutledge to G. R. Rutledge describing the state of his current encampment near his Uncle Sam and Aunt Elzira's property. He explains that due to pillaging by the army the local population now despises the Confederate army almost as much as they do the Union army; tells of the death of Tim Miller, brother to Captain Sam; and comments on the condition of Uncle Sam's and Aunt Elzira's families and his own health.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Correspondence from J. S. Burrow to F. T. Burrow, February 16, 1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation:
[Page 1]
“Jacks Creek February 16th 1862 Der Brother I received your Letter I was very glad to her that you was all well it found all of you sad that you had jest got home from a visit at the fort I was prod to her that Nick was well I wold be glad to se him & the balanc of you but times is so hard & mony scars I can not tell when I can com you Sad Sumphen a bout me a comin thar to work I recon that I cold make more thar then I can her but I havent got money to pay my way thar but if I had money I wold move thar as sone as I cold git thar but I can not colect Eny money at this time unless Coton cam in markett I cold git to wark for the goverment her if I cold leave my famley but I cant git no pursen to stay with them I wish I cold git a way from her for I am gitin tierd of the plase I can make a livin her and that is all I cant make Eny money over that theer is a good deale of Exsitement her sence the linkens its have took forte henry but I think that ginerl Piller will retake it a gin if he can git farse a nuff the nuse is that he has whipe them at forte donelsin but I dont no that it is the case the Boys is all gon from her this place is vary lomson now som of them is in the Cavlery & som in inferny thar is fore or five men left her McCarkle & houston Tablen chris her”
[Page 2]
“& my self but I donte know how longe we will git to stay if the war continus I Exspect we will all have to go this is a distresin times on us but we will have to fite or Run & I donte think the Tenessee Boys will Run much Chris did git a letter from Brouther Wiley ses he is comin back her as son as he can I am vary lomson her know sence the boys is gon but thar ar stain at Henderson depo 9 miles from her you must excuse my letter paper for I cant git Eny other sorte onley Book paper Right when you can & I will do the same so I will close with these few lines I Remain your Lovin Brother un tell deth I S Burro To F T Burro & famley”
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: J. S. Burrow writes his brother from Chester County detailing his financial problems, his inability to collect money until cotton comes to market, his desire to move from Jacks Creek for better money-making opportunities, and his fear that he will eventually have to enter military service. He contends General Pillow will re-take Ft. Henry if he can muster enough troops. He notes that unconfirmed rumors state Pillow has whipped the enemy at Fort Donelson.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Burrow, J.S.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Confederate earthworks protecting the Tennessee and Cumberland Rivers fell to Federal troops in February 1862. The attack from Union ironclads brought down Fort Henry on February 6, 1862, prior to the arrival of Federal soldiers overland. A longer battle involving both army and navy was required to bring down Fort Donelson on February 16, 1862. Thus, the North had its first major victory and entre into the heart of the South.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Tennessee General Claims Commission
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Tennessee General Assembly formed the General Claims Commission February 19, 1868, to compensate loyal citizens who suffered property losses at the hands of Union or Confederate forces and to pay unpaid wages. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Small document serving as an oath of allegiance of Mont. T. Byrn of Williamson County to the United States government. The oath was taken at Nashville, Tennessee, on February 12, 1864.

The Oath of Allegiance, also called the Loyalty Oath, was a document signed by persons during and after the Civil War to pledge loyalty and allegiance to the Union. Initially intended for employees of the Federal government and military personnel, the oath soon took several different forms and eventually extended to the state level. Employment and business ownership were then dependent on signed oaths.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John Thomas Wright Affidavit
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: “John Thomas Wright being duly sworn testifies as follows: There were two companies of cavalry organized in Lebanon, that became members of the 4th Tenn. Cavalry, commanded by Col. Baxter Smith. Company F was commanded by Capt. J. R. Lester and Company K was commanded by Capt. Jim Britton. I belonged to Company F from its organization until it was paroled by Charlotte, N. C. on May 3, 1865. On the record I made, I am now on the pension roll of Tennessee. Mr. Huse Burke did not belong to either of said companies, nor to the 4th Tenn. Cavalry: However, he had a brother, James Burke who did belong to Company F, and made a gallant soldier, and was killed in a charge at the battle of Chickamauga on September 20, 1863. If Mr. Huse Burke was ever tried or threatened to be tried by a Federal Court martial, it was as a citizen and not as a member of the 4th Tennessee Cavalry. Jno. T. Wright Sworn to before me, this 24 day of February, 1923. [signature] Notary Public”
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Affidavit of John Thomas Wright concerning the 4th Tennessee Cavalry, Mr. James Burke and Mr. Hurse Burke. He testifies that a Mr. Hurse Burke did not belong to either of these companies or to the 4th Tennessee Cavalry, but that his brother, James Burke, did belong to one of these two companies.
